rules: Rule1: Either the oak grows in the forest or the forest's habitat is preserved.
Rule2: Whenever the oak is protected, it is not endangered.
Rule3: If the oak study is completed, then it undergoes peer review.

Rule4: Whenever the government mandates the protection program, then if it is not the case that peer review of the oak study implies that approved conservation grant funding leads to protection of the oak when non-nativeness or absence from the forest implies invasiveness, the oak study becomes controversial.
Rule5: Either the botanist studied the oak or the ecologist studied the oak.

Rule6: Under the condition that the ecologist studied the oak, then if the oak being non-native to Europe or not growing in the forest leads to it being invasive in the forest, the oak is not endangered.

Rule7: Provided that the journal published the oak study, then if the botanist studied the oak, whenever the oak being non-native to Europe or not growing in the forest implies it is invasive in the forest, the oak is not endangered.
Rule8: Either the journal published the oak study or the conference presented the oak study.

Rule9: Under the condition that it is not the case that peer review of the oak study implies that approved conservation grant funding leads to protection of the oak when non-nativeness or absence from the forest implies invasiveness, then the oak study is not controversial.
Rule10: If the oak is non-native to Europe or does not grow in the forest, then it is not invasive in the forest.

Rule11: Provided that it is not the case that presentation at the conference of the oak study implies that the botanist's study of the oak leads to non-endangerment when non-nativeness or absence from the forest implies invasiveness, then the oak study is award-winning.

Rule12: Under the condition that it is not the case that presentation at the conference of the oak study implies that the botanist's study of the oak leads to non-endangerment when non-nativeness or absence from the forest implies invasiveness, then the oak study is not award-winning.
Rule13: If the oak being non-native to Europe or not growing in the forest does not lead to it being invasive in the forest, then the oak is endangered.
facts: Fact1: Funding for the conservation grant is approved.
Fact2: The oak study is research completed.
Fact3: The government mandated the protection program.
Fact4: The oak is not native to Europe.
